_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Youngstown's Waste Water Treatment Plant (facility or Youngstown WWTP) is committed to the safety and health of our employees, our community, and our environment. To this end, we have formal policies and procedures in place through our Safety Manual and our Risk Management Plan. We have committed senior management resources for the ongoing development, implementation and integration of the program elements into our overall operations.



The WWTP provides primary treatment, flocculation, clarification, secondary treatment, and disinfection for customers in the City of Youngstown and other portions of Mahoning and Trumbull Counties. The facility is designed to process an average wastewater flow of 35 million gallons per day (MGD) with a maximum of 90 MGD. The WWTP uses UV as a primary means of disinfection for up to 80 million gallons per day (MGD). Chlorine is used to chlorinate the wastewater that exceeds 80 MGD. Sulfur dioxide is used to dechlorinate wastewater in excess of 80 MGD.



The facility has implemented Prevention Program 3 requirements that includes the following elements: Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analyses, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Pre-startup Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permit, and Contractors. Operating and maintenance procedures are key to operating the system in a safe manner and these are routinely reviewed and updated. The maintenance of key equipment such as automatic shutdown systems, sensors, and alarm systems is critical to the ongoing safety of our process.



The facility has had no accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide in the past five years.



The facility is a non-responding facility and has coordinated its emergency response with the Mahoning County HazMat Team as responders in the event of a chlorine or sulfur dioxide emergency. The facility has developed chlorine and sulfur dioxide emergency procedures include

d in the Emergency Action Plan of the Safety Manual. Emergency response procedures outline emergency notification requirements. In addition, emergency response training and exercises are conducted to prepare our employees in the event of a release.



The Youngstown WWTP is currently reviewing the required inventory of chlorine and sulfur dioxide to be stored on-site to satisfy operating requirements with the intent to minimize the amount stored to minimize risk. The continual review and update of operating and maintenance procedures is performed to improve the overall safety of the system.
